title-group.subtitle: Collaborative Leadership Lost in Translation? An Exploration

bio.title: Author biographies
bio.p: Marlene Morrison is Emeritus Professor of Education at the Westminster Institute of Education where she was Research Director. Her research and teaching interests lie in leadership for learning with a specific interest in matters of social justice and inclusion. Publications reflect her long-standing substantive and methodological interests.
Linet Arthur is Senior Lecturer, also at the Westminster Institute, with specific teaching and research interests in the leadership and management of change.

abstract.p: Collaborative leadership is increasingly cited as the key framework for leadership in the 21st century. Yet its meaning remains complex, contested and frequently school-centric. This article examines understandings and applications in developing inter-service and inter-professional practices for children and young people. Drawing upon desk research from the fields of education, health, social care, and social work, base-line literary analysis is used to interrogate leadership. In addressing the implications for ELM theory and practice when engagement beyond single organizations and services becomes the ‘norm’, the article looks towards more futures-orientated leadership theory and research that both define and develop the capabilities needed to lead learning in inter-professional, inter-agency environments, including schools.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The increasing clamour for ‘collaboration’ as the key framework for leadership in the 21st century, not least in school contexts (Hallinger and Heck, 2010; Marks and Printy, 2003; Mulford and Silins, 2003), seems unabated. Yet, attempts to establish its precise meaning remain complex and contested. As Morrison and Glenny (forthcoming) point out:

disp-quote.p: [Its] … appeal is enticing [and] extends from the macro-levels of the ‘collaborative state’ (Parker and Gallagher, 2007) to the structures, processes, practices, and ultimately professional development and training of its citizens, especially those charged with enacting new modes of service provision across the public/private divide.

sec.p: As our opening references suggest, much of the focus upon collaborative leadership in education has been framed within school research, and often in the context of school networks or clusters which are assumed to be ‘collaborative groups’ that ‘empower localities’ (Paterson and Ireson, 2011). While use of the term ‘collaborative leadership’ extends back to earlier international school leadership discourses, for example, Lugg and Boyd (1993) and Smylie (1992), and to discussions of leadership in the ‘(post)modern era’ (Goddard, 2003: 17), as ‘effective’ leadership(Riley and MacBeath, 2003), and in relation to ‘new models’ for more facilitative, democratic leaders in educational partnerships (Briggs, 2009), the term has remained largely overshadowed by or absorbed within other leadership model discourses. Our core interest lies not in collaboration as a concept that is exclusive to schools, but rather its usefulness as a framework for meeting UK policy objectives to integrate services for children and young people. However, this does not exclude interest in school leadership, and for at least two reasons. First, schools and school principals respectively are viewed explicitly by policymakers as among a range of core service sites and leaders to activate and sustain integrated service provision. In England, for example, this stance is embraced by the National College of Leadership for Schools and Children’s Service (NCLSCS), where school leaders are identified as key agents in effecting an inter-agency/multi-agency perspective, albeit within a predominantly school effectiveness/school improvement priority. This means that, second, schools and school leaders are simultaneously both the intended targets of UK policy interventions claimed to be ‘collaborative’, and are also named (indeed, increasingly, name themselves) as among a range of instigators, agitators even, for increased inter-agency activity in the interests of children and young people. This is sometimes referred to in terms of leadership for community and/or extended schooling that is coupled with multi-agency engagement, and, above all, a sense of ‘child-centredness’ and operational arrangements that involve various kinds of team working. For some schools, such engagement extends to the physical presence of and activities by multi-agency workers on the school site, and/or include either strongly or weakly framed joint activities (Coleman, 2006).

Despite such trends, the generic terms ‘collaboration’ and ‘collaborative leadership’ remain ill-defined conceptually (but see Close, 2011), and empirical investigations are relatively sparse. Superficial conceptual ‘seepage’ is multi-directional, with assumptions that what collaborative leadership means for schools, for example, might, with relative ease, be transferrable to the leadership of other services for children and young people, to leadership of a range of intra- and/or inter-agency services, and vice versa. At best, advocacy seems to be towards ‘some kind of hybrid [leadership] model’ (Purcell, 2009: 2, emphasis added), that absorbs or lists existing literatures.

sec.title: Purpose
sec.p: The purpose of this article, then, is twofold. A first task is to unpack what might be ‘lost in translation’ when ‘collaboration’, ‘collaborative leadership’ and a panoply of loosely associated terms are converted into various practices, including leadership capacity building and the identification of those in whom leadership might reside. A second task is to consider the robustness of leadership models in use, not least those which are school-centric. Discussion draws from extant literatures in education, health, social care, and social work, in order to develop a base-line analysis to interrogate leadership and management for collaborative inter-service practice.

Desk research draws from one element of an inter-departmental project among colleagues at the Westminster Institute of Education (now School of Education) and the Department of Health and Social Care (see acknowledgements) at Oxford Brookes University, UK. In 2009–2010, this included joint seminar engagement and a literature review (of publications from 1980) mainly across the fields of Education, Health and Social Care. Given that effective leadership appeared to be increasingly cited as a key determinant of whether boundary-crossing work between services would succeed or fail, this provided one of several main focal points of interest.

This article outlines the background to inter-agency activities; identifies the context of inter-agency work in Education, including schools; analyses leadership approaches, roles and models considered appropriate to collaborative activities across services; and discusses the professional development of inter-agency leaders.

sec.title: Background
sec.p: Despite growing interest in the leadership of intra-service provision, namely collaborations, for example, between schools (Chapman, 2008; Chapman et al., 2008; Hallinger and Heck, 2010), or between various constituents of, for example, Health and Social Care provision (Barr, 2010; Cameron et al., 2009; Carpenter et al., 2006; Meads and Ashcroft, 2005), explorations of leadership of or for inter-service practice remain relatively sparse (but see Close and Wainwright, 2010; Edwards et al., 2009, 2010; Glenny and Roaf, 2008; Hammick et al., 2009; Morrison and Glenny, 2011). Moreover, with exceptions (for example, Lumby and Morrison, 2006), preferences in the education leadership and management field have been to research leadership in terms of relationships between individuals or groups within single organizations, usually schools. As our opening comments suggest, ‘collaborative leadership’ has become an ‘operational construct’ (Hallinger and Heck, 2010: 657) to consider within-school collaborations, their links (or not) to school improvement, and whether they improve organizational (Mulford and Silins, 2003) or students’ learning (Hallinger and Heck, 2010).

In the earlier literature such constructs have also been considered in relation to ‘collegial’ (rather than collaborative) models of school leadership in which ‘the collegial leader is not so much a star standing alone as the developer of consensus among … professionals who must share the burden of … decisions’ (Baldridge et al., 1978: 45, quoted in Bush, 1995: 64). In collegial models, the emphasis has been upon leadership as facilitating team work and participation among staff (and, latterly, students), and is underpinned by the ‘authority of expertise rather than official authority’ (Bush, 1995: 65). Along with previous exhortations to demonstrate collegiality have come concerns about the limitations of collegial approaches, notably with reference to their impractical or cumbersome processes, and the validity of assumptions about the possibility, or, indeed, desirability of consensus among all staff.

Interestingly, such concerns (see later section) resonate with more recent discussion about the personal, social, economic, and education transaction costs of inter-agency collaboration, not least in terms of leaders needing to manage different professional fields, ideologies, organizational priorities and outcome measures. Equally, a more fundamental criticism of collegiality relates to its potentially ‘contrived’ nature (Hargreaves, 1994: 195-196), when collegial models are ‘administratively regulated’, ‘instigated compulsorily’ rather than with discretion, geared to the implementation of government or school principal mandates, and/or ‘designed for predictable outcomes’. Again, such early concerns signal the potential for accelerating challenges that might be faced by leaders tasked with leading and prioritizing among collaborations of increased scale and scope.

Given these ‘early warning’ literatures, paucity in attention to inter-service leadership is surprizing, particularly in view of an espoused policy preference for ‘Teams-Around-the-Child (TAC)’ models of inter-service provision (CWDC, 2010; DFES, 2004; Evangelou et al., 2009), and cultural shifts towards ‘collaborative community’ (Hartley, 2010a: 347) as the new multi-organizational form in which the knowledge economy might be developed, not least to get ‘social management and policy work done’ (Ball, 2008: 762). Even TAC models are open to multiple interpretation, referring commonly, at the micro-level, to case conferences for children and young people that might occur regularly, if infrequently, for children with statemented needs, for example, but also, in another sense, to generic frameworks that imply larger-scale, team-orientated engagement between all services for children and young people. Indeed, as this article will suggest, such approaches have provided multiple drivers towards current leadership capacity building programmes.

sec.title: Every Child Matters
sec.p: The Every Child Matters (ECM) agenda (DFES, 2004) and its aftermath has sharpened the focus upon inter-agency work, ECM requiring a co-ordinated response to children’s needs that brings together school-based educators, social workers, general practitioners, educational psychologists, health workers, parents/carers, children and others. (Most recently, volunteers and volunteering activities are also given prominence.) It is based on the premise that multi-disciplinary teamwork is essential for delivering integrated children’s services (DFES, 2006a). While the concept of ‘joined-up’ services to meet children’s various social and educational needs might appear eminently sensible (Glenny and Roaf, 2008; Cameron et al., 2009), conceptual as well as practical challenges in leading multi-agency work are various, and often obscured. Indeed, some commentators have argued that collaborative inter-agency activity should be avoided altogether unless absolutely necessary (Huxham and Vangen, 2005) often because the social, educational, economic and/or reputational costs (Lawson, 2004) of engagement are much higher for some agents than for others, and are, indeed, high for all parties involved. Other commentators have continued to emphasize traditional structures of leadership, whether in schools (Cameron et al., 2009) or Children’s Centres (Stacey, 2009).

sec.title: Policy Rhetoric
sec.p: The rhetoric of the ‘greater good’ for children resonates through all recent policy initiatives, ECM (DFES, 2004) being preceded and superseded (DCSF, 2010) by numerous exhortations towards networking, partnership, collaboration, and extended systems for schools and other services: for example, Extended Schools (DFES, 2005b), Excellence in Cities (DFEE, 1998), Sure Start (DFE, 2010), Multi-agency Working (2005a) and Youth Matters (DFES, 2006b). ECM provided a national framework for 150 local programmes of change, which were intended to be led by local authorities and their partners, and which included more detailed outcomes for Inspectorates ‘to inform local needs analysis and the monitoring of progress towards priority targets and indicators’ (DFES, 2004: 1). This would be assessed through ‘targeted inspection activity explicitly around clear outcomes for children, and focused on the user, unconstrained by service boundaries’ (DFES, 2004: 1, emphasis added).

For schools as well as related Health and Social Care services, ECM has been one aspect of policy for social engineering, that has also included emphases upon Early Years Education, 14-19 Education, careers guidance, peer mentoring, and ‘citizenship’ focused activities. Smith (2005) is among commentators to cast doubt upon the feasibility or, indeed, appropriate nature of such an all-encompassing embrace (Delgado, 2002; Davies, 2005). Reasons cited are both pragmatic and ideological: historical records of integrated services for children working badly or patchily (a fear echoed by OECD, 2004), and a reluctance among schools to accommodate disciplinary or service frameworks different from their own (Smith, 2005).

That noted, the National College, with its growing commitment to ‘networked’ and/or ‘system’ leadership (NCLSCS 2010a, 2010b, 2010c) and school clusters has signalled its determination to move towards leadership development for integrated practices. This is set against a backdrop of policy initiatives that are increasingly located in the ephemera of surface, measurable outcomes. Intended to counteract poor intra- as well as inter-service delivery (Hoyle, 2008), such measures, it is argued, tend to sidestep deep structural inequalities. Across all services, poorly co-ordinated provision is to be remedied by better forms of inter-professional training or working (Whittington, 2003), although, in existing forms, Munro (2004) is among commentators to have argued that these are unlikely to optimize the potential for ‘deep’ benefit for service users.

sec.title: Collaboration and Partnership
sec.p: It is through partnerships that the benefit potential for individual agencies to work together for ‘the greater good’ of service users (Mordaunt, 1999) will, it is asserted, be maximized. That this potential is not always realized (Lumby and Foskett, 2005: 146) or even, at organizational level, intended (Lumby and Morrison, 2006), is also recognized. Lumby and Foskett (2005: 146), for example, refer to some forms of ‘partnership’ as ritualistic, with individual partners gaining much kudos by the public presentation of partnership while allowing each partner ‘to continue much as they have done in the past’. Earlier, Mordaunt (1999) went even farther in describing ‘predatory partnerships’ in which collaborations, frequently spearheaded by individual leaders, gain advantage at the cost of other collaborators, with few discernible benefits to service users.
Collaboration is described as distinct from partnership, yet both are frequently used interchangeably (Morrison and Glenny, 2011). In the inter-professional literature, collaboration is defined as:

disp-quote.p: An active and ongoing partnership, often between people of diverse backgrounds, who work together to solve problems or provide services and share experiences. (Hammick et al., 2009: 205)

sec.p: Collaboration, it is asserted, also differs from cooperation or coordination:

disp-quote.p: Co-operation and co-ordination are less elaborate and ambitious ways of working together. Being co-operative means being open, willing and able to work with others … [W]hen undertaking co-ordination activities people primarily focus upon the timing and sequencing of working together. (Hammick et al., 2009: 205)

sec.p: These distinctions remain fuzzy, not least when leadership as collaboration and/or partnership and/or networking are co-joined. Between schools, for example, Hadfield (2007) refers to ‘inter-organizational networks’. In relation to inter-professional service provision, Whittington (2003: 16) refers to ‘a lexicon of partnership and collaboration’ described in the following terms:

disp-quote.p: Partnership is a state of relationships, at organizational, group, professional or inter-professional level, to be achieved, maintained, and reviewed; and collaboration is the active process of partnership in action.

sec.p: Elsewhere, Frost (2005) identifies four possible levels of partnership for inter-agency provision: cooperation, collaboration, co-ordination, and merger/fusion. More ‘bounded’ collaborations have clear targets, time-limits, and include distinctive contributions from each agency. In distinguishing between multi- and inter-professional working, Whittington (2003) and Øvretveit et al. (1997) contrast (multi)professionals working cooperatively in parallel, while continuing to operate in separate organizations, with (inter-agency) ‘partners’ who take a more integrated approach.

However, the ‘messy’ and potentially tense nature of inter-service collaboration is not ignored by inter-service writers. Agencies may be subject to different legislative or policy frameworks, which may lead to principals, whether of schools or other agencies, feeling distracted from their core roles and functions. Evidence is also cited of unclear lines of authority, and being held accountable for system problems over which they have limited control and/or resources (Anning et al., 2006; Cameron et al., 2009). Demarcation issues may be ethical and professional as well as legislative (Siraj Blatchford et al., 2007), and are magnified amidst rapid change and initiative proliferation. Operational challenges may be accentuated by structural and cultural clashes, where aims and objectives of collaboration may be hidden (Huxham and Vangen, 2005; Coleman, 2006), misunderstood, or undermined by competing priorities (Cameron et al., 2009).

Macbeath et al. (2007: ch. 3) note how challenges intensify when inter-agency or multi-agency working is intended for schools and communities already immersed in the actualities of multiple ‘disadvantage’ and ‘challenging circumstance’. From the user’s perspective (still relatively unusual in the field) and drawing upon social capital theory, Macbeath et al. remind readers of the pressures in bridging the capacity of service users to access people in positions of power and authority in order to obtain resources, not least where interrelationships between schooling, housing, social services, health and employment opportunities seem fractured and discordant to service users.

In the following section, the concepts underpinning the main leadership models applied to date in the inter-agency field are introduced, along with consideration of the strengths and challenges evoked by their application.

sec.title: Leadership for Inter-agency Collaboration
sec.p: Our desk research suggests that, to date, mainstream leadership and management theory has struggled to move beyond the assumed transferability of leadership theories for single organizational entities towards deep interrogations of leadership for inter-agency work, especially beyond schools (but see Huxham and Vangen, 2005; Glenny and Roaf, 2008; Kirwan et al., 2008). Much existing education leadership theory assumes a formal leader of a single hierarchical structure. In contrast, the nature of inter-agency collaboration typically includes: complex inter-agency hierarchies; the absence of formal leadership authority vested in one person; instability in the tenure of inter-agency working groups; a multiplicity of agendas; ambiguity in membership; dynamic states of disequilibrium; and unclear/competing aims to resolve ‘wicked problems’ (Lawson, 2004). Edwards et al. (2010) argue that more traditional path-finding, vision-building aspects of leadership (Fullan, 1991) have little place in inter-professional working especially where leaders lack formal authority over other members of inter-professional groups. Instead, Edwards et al. prefer to focus upon the relational skills needed to engage group members. In contrast, Hammick et al. (2009) suggest that vision-building leadership is even more necessary when the need is to establish appropriate working relations, often in precarious inter-organizational frameworks.

In some policy-centred discourses the term ‘leadership’ is almost avoided altogether. Rather, the emphasis is upon management and operational skills. For example, the Hay Group’s Report (2008), The Training and Development of Middle Managers in the Children’s Workforce (Hartle et al., 2008), refers throughout to ‘managers’, as does the DFES (2006a) report, Championing Children. While the latter identifies some leadership activities for the managers of integrated children’s services – vision-building, developing policy, modelling inclusive behaviour and maintaining a focus on common purpose – an overriding assumption is that managing operational aspects of multi-agency work, will, in most cases, be sufficient for effective collaboration. Elsewhere, the role of ‘lead professionals’ in Team-Around-the-Child models is viewed as transient and complex; the latter is reinforced when it is noted that ‘lead professionals’ are neither ‘responsible [n]or accountable for the activities/services of other professionals/services’ (Children’s Workforce Development Council [CWDC], 2010), depending instead upon post-holders’ inter-personal skills to co-ordinate provision.

Two different levels of multi-agency collaboration are distinguishable: the strategic and the service delivery (Coleman, 2006). Whittington (2003) identifies different types of collaboration in social work, which also depend upon levels of integration and whether there is a strategic or operational focus. A tension exists between leadership approaches at these different levels. Directive leadership at the strategic level may undermine the more informal relationships which support effective service delivery (Glenny and Roaf, 2008).

Coleman (2006) argues that it is preferable for the staff of external agencies to be line-managed by their own agencies, rather than by headteachers, even when agencies are located on the school site. Yet this also creates problems for individuals especially when there are multiple temporal demands, line managers are located elsewhere, and with different priorities. Duffy and Marshall (2007: 111) note the challenges presented by divided priorities for staff seconded to children’s centres, for example, an issue also recognized by the DFES (2006a: 11).

Research by Axelsson and Axelsson (2009: 324) focuses upon multi-agency work, especially in relation to teams, and from the perspective of vertical (hierarchical) and horizontal (voluntary) integration. In many multi-agency activities, they argue: ‘horizontal collaboration in multi-disciplinary teams is combined with vertical co-ordination by the agencies involved’. If describing such activities as team-work (rather than looser-knit networks) might be stretching the term ‘team’ too far, the fluidity of such arrangements appears to describe a current management ‘reality’ in many intermediate agency activities that are increasingly connected to and within schools. Faced by multiple demands, research participants perceived that their careers could be adversely affected if they prioritized the needs of multi-agency collaboration over those of their organization. Elsewhere, Edwards et al. (2010) identify potential challenges for practitioners who work at professional boundaries and ‘bend rules’ for the sake of the collaboration.

In recommendations arising from these various research studies, several writers advocate new approaches to professionalism, not least that ‘inter-professionality’ is seriously implicated in inter-agency work. Axelsson and Axelsson (2009) recommend the sacrifice of professional interests and territory, based on traditional forms of professional altruism, in favour of putting collaboration first, as does Whittington (2003: 53) earlier: advocacy is for ‘professional allegiances … to make room for team membership’ underpinned by emerging insights into inter-professional practice. The then DCSF (2008: 9) refers to the need for professionals to create ‘a culture of inter-agency working whereby the needs of children, young people and families transcend traditional professional perspectives’. In terms of inter-educational partnerships, Briggs (2009: 248) refers to the need both for new ‘structures and activities’ and ways of thinking about leadership.

sec.title: Defining Leaders
sec.p: Various names have been used to define those who are given or required to take lead roles in inter- or multi-agency activities. In the Hay Group Report (2008: 40) Hartle et al. describe such persons as co-ordinators, who work ‘with others … networking, gaining trust and respect and building effective relationships’. The role has also been referred to as: extended schools co-ordinator (Coleman, 2006), networker (Kirwan et al., 2008), boundary spanner (Frost, 2005), welfare manager (Edwards et al., 2010), system minder (Glenny and Roaf, 2008) and partnership manager (Vangen and Huxham, 2003), each with a slightly different emphasis. Nevertheless, there are striking similarities between these roles in terms of attempts to ‘stretch’ leadership beyond the boundaries of single organizations, use ‘orchestration’ tactics rather than positional power to gain cooperation, and emphasizing their roles as facilitators.

There is a surprising absence of emphasis upon the name-holders’ power and influence and/or lack of either or both. According to Glenny and Roaf (2008: 41), ‘successful minders … hold the ring’ and focus the evolving ‘collective memory’ of the collaborating group. Their research findings suggest that the role of the ‘minder’ is to monitor developing consensus, and ensure that this is ‘faithfully represented and maintained’ (Glenny and Roaf, 2008: 41). System minders operate, then, as ‘norm holders’, receiving issues and concerns, and monitoring task completion (Glenny and Roaf, 2008: 43, 44). In this sense, partnership leaders (however described) are often referred to as a ‘resource’ rather than as ‘full leaders’ (Huxham and Vangen, 2005). This may lead to the adoption of leadership approaches that seem inconsistent with ‘the spirit of collaboration’ (Vangen and Huxham, 2003: 70). ‘Collaborative thuggery’ (Glenny and Roaf, 2008: 40) is described as manipulative and political behaviours to achieve collaborative advantage, and there are important echoes here in terms of Hargreaves’ (1994) early study of ‘contrived’ collegiality in schools. In the absence of other formal means to encourage members to take action, ‘collaborative thuggery’ (Vangen and Huxham, 2003), it is contended, is not necessarily negative. Indeed, it may be the only pragmatic option available to lead professionals in collaborative partnerships. Nonetheless, preference is still expressed for a ‘nurturing process’ (Vangen and Huxham, 2003: 152) throughout collaborative activity, rather than activities which prioritize ends over (any) means.

Other challenges pertain to status and hierarchy. Within organizations like schools, inter-agency work is increasingly spearheaded by staff, frequently known as ‘welfare managers’, who occupy a lower professional status than teachers, and this is reflected in lower pay and lack of a ‘codified’ knowledge base (Edwards et al., 2010). Elsewhere, Hartley (2010a: 360) declares, even more provocatively, that there remains, as yet, minimal evidence to suggest that ‘the collaborative community’ being espoused at levels of leadership and/or in inter-agency provision, exists ‘within the site of production – [in the case of schools] the classroom or other pedagogical space’.

sec.title: Leadership Models
sec.p: That the effective practice of inter-agency provision for children and young people depends upon effective leadership has become almost a truism. The received policy wisdom is that with training, up-scaling, up-skilling, and more team work and team leadership, provision will be enhanced and more successfully integrated. This might suggest that the legacy of the lone ‘heroic’ leader has less resonance in inter-service than uni-service provision. However, our desk review suggests that the ideological ‘pull’ of such a legacy should not be under-estimated, either currently or historically, especially when ‘heroism’ is linked to transformation (Cummings, 2008). In times of inter-service crisis, rallying cries for heroic leaders to pull together the strings of discordant provision, or indeed, carry the burden of approbation when, as in cases of child protection failures, for example, services are seen to fail service users (Laming, 2003, 2009; Munro, 2004), remains strong.

sec.title: Transformational Leadership
sec.p: Transformational leadership is strongly recommended in the inter-professional (Axelsson and Axelsson, 2009; Cummings, 2008; Coleman, 2006) and other literature (Hall et al., 2002). Axelsson and Axelsson (2009: 325), for example, argue that the altruism required for managers to ‘see their own agency in a larger perspective based on the needs of their client’, is transformational. Elsewhere, Cummings (2008: 5) suggests that transformational leadership is characterizized by ‘creativity, emotional intelligence and a capacity for personal growth, along with sophisticated negotiation and consultation skills and the ability to empower others’. Less positively, concerns about transformational leadership also mirror those in the Education Leadership and Management (ELM) literatures, not least prospects of domination by one ‘collaborating’ partner (Lawson, 2004) and the capacity for unequal power relations to undermine collaborative work (Cummings, 2008; Glenny and Roaf, 2008).

Meanwhile, as Gronn (2010: 416, emphasis added) suggests, the conceptual ‘closeness’ of the ‘heroic’/charismatic and the ‘transformational’ continues to be problematic: first, ‘charisma is very like the defining attribute of idealized [rather than ‘real’] influence in transformational leadership’. Second, as leadership concepts, they represent in exaggerated forms the extent to which one person can/does ‘make a difference’ (Gronn, 2010: 416). Third, and perhaps most significantly, such terms have never fully represented ‘the reality of leadership and decision-making’, not least in schools during recent reforming eras (Gronn, 2010: 416). This suggests that the borrowing of such terms for the even larger leadership ventures envisaged in inter-service provision might always be problematic. That this is, in part, recognized helps to explain the turn towards other models.

sec.title: Distributed Leadership
sec.p: There are two key mantras in the advocacy of inter-agency collaborative practice: the first is that effective inter-service provision is reliant upon ‘learning and working in a variety of teams’ (Hammick et al., 2009: 38, 54); the second is that working in teams requires effective leaders. As in education, and, in particular, schools, advocacy draws upon various versions of distributed leadership, although rationales are sometimes implicit rather than explicit. This is unsurprising given that both distributed leadership and new forms of inter-professional and inter-service collaborative practice share close affinities with the ‘new work order’ of late modern societies (Hartley, 2010b: 282). These draw increasingly upon project-based Teams-Around-the-Child models of working, described earlier by Gee et al. (1996). As Hartley (2010b: 282) suggests, distributed leadership appeals to ‘a culture of weakened codes of certainty’ in which ‘identities – be they of occupational role or social identity – no longer have the durability or clarity they once enjoyed’. Indeed, tensions about changing professional identities, not least at the boundaries of inter-professional working are identified in numerous publications, in Education as well as interprofessional Care (Adams, 2005; Calder and Grieve, 2004; Carpenter et al., 2003) and in relation to changing trajectories for professionalism and career (McLaughlin, 1997; Riehl and Troman, 2008; Robinson et al. (2005); Sachs, 2004).

At macro-levels, distributed leadership sits particularly well with new forms of ‘political theory’ (Hartley, 2010b) that are being translated as integrated practices. These involve more than exhortations towards ‘joined up’ government but also to new directions in the ‘co-configuration’ (Edwards et al., 2009) of services for children and young people. The turn towards integrated provision and distributed leadership, is inter-linked to terms like team, system, and servant leadership (see below). In this sense, ‘new’ leadership draws upon established theoretical labels or no labels at all, given the tendency among leadership developers (see later section) to eschew the theoretical in favour of what they assume practitioners will value more, that is, direct appeals to self-reflection and/or exemplars from fellow trainees. This fails to recognize that the development of ‘new’ theory has potential to provide/inform the understandings and practices both of individual leaders as well as communities of research-informed practitioners.
Gronn (2010: 417) usefully identifies two main understandings of distributed leadership. In the inter-professional literatures, these are rarely distinguished. He writes:

disp-quote.p: If the way leadership works is described as distributed, then this may be because there is more than one leader … That it is to say the totality of organizational influence is not concentrated in or monopolised by just one person, but instead is dispersed or shared around, so that there are a number of sources of influence, initiative-taking or forward-thinking. This way of thinking about distributed leadership can be characterised as atomistic …

The second … meaning might be described as holistic. What is entailed here is small numbers of people, who, for various reasons, may have established close working relationships over a period of time, with the result that they operate, in effect, as a joint or collective unit.

sec.p: ‘Atomistic’ forms of distributed leadership are commonly applied to individuals who delegate authority or responsibility to others, and include behaviours commonly used in performance management, and, more recently, in relation to ‘box-ticking’ standards indicators for ECM (Cheminais, 2007). More noticeable as rhetoric than as researched practice, ‘holistic’ forms focus upon ‘people’s interdependence or mutual dependence and the ways in which their reliance on each other provides a basis for … blending in productive partnerships that might otherwise be separate sets of skills’ (Gronn, 2010: 418). Inter-agency ‘cooperation’ and ‘co-ordination’ infer distributed leadership of a more atomistic kind, while ‘collaboration’ is more akin to the ‘holistic’ models described by Gronn (2010).

Distributed leadership has been advocated more or less continuously as the recommended approach for the evolutionary processes of inter-agency work, allowing, it is suggested, school staff to contribute to the multi-agency focus, without dominating activities (Coleman, 2006; Cummings, 2008; Duffy and Marshall, 2007; Kirwan et al., 2008; Siraj Blatchford and Manni, 2007). In such arrangements, the distinctions between distributed and delegated leadership are often unclear, referring to practices whereby single organizations delegate membership of collaborative inter-service groups to particular staff, as well as indicating an approach to leading such a group. An exception is Coleman (2006) who suggests that leadership ought to be distributed across partner organizations and the wider community. Less in evidence are published projects/research to demonstrate how this is occurring/might occur. Research findings by Siraj Blatchford and Manni (2007: 21) are cautiously optimistic about the integrative potential of distributed leadership, arguing that ‘it should not be seen as a "simple panacea"’. Among the challenging issues identified, frequently in relation to research centred upon the establishment of children’s centres (see also DFES, 2003), the following are apposite:
Leaders of schools and children’s centres may feel that it is too risky to distribute leadership for areas of work for which they will ultimately be held responsible (Coleman, 2006).

list-item.p: Pay differentials make some staff reluctant to take on extra responsibilities (Siraj Blatchford et al., 2007; Anning et al., 2006).
Early Years practitioners may not yet have appropriate qualifications and/or experience to engage in leadership activities (Siraj Blatchford and Manni, 2007).
Relatively high rates of staff turnover in contributing agencies challenge prospects for continuity of purpose and action (Huxham and Vangen, 2005).
Practitioners working with children may be unaware of their contribution, potential and actual, to integrated service provision (Stacey, 2009).

sec.p: Elsewhere, Edwards et al. (2010) refer to ‘distributed expertise’ rather than distributed leadership; this is linked to specialist knowledge and the ability to work with others in order to respond to the complexity of children’s needs. Positively, it is argued, ‘distributed expertise’ enhances the capacity for individuals to work ‘with others to strengthen purposeful responses to complex problems’ (Edwards et al., 2010: 31). ‘Contributive’ leadership (Kirwan et al., 2008), a term less well-known than ‘distributed’, is used to describe leadership that is more fluid and less formal in terms of lead members’ responsibilities, tasks and accountabilities. In summary, Kirwan et al. (2008) suggest that ‘multi-agency leadership’ requires a combination of ‘contributive’ and ‘distributive’ (rather than distributed) leadership.

sec.title: Leaderless, Elective, Team and Servant Leadership
sec.p: In 2006, the then Minister of State for Education, Beverley Hughes, outlined the leadership and management qualities needed for the successful delivery of the ECM agenda stating that:

disp-quote.p: We need leaders and managers who can build teams competent and confident in this new means of service delivery; who will put the child and family first; who can lead those from outside their own areas of expertise; who can manage resources in new ways; and who can reconcile team members’ different working practices and expectations. (DFES, 2006a: 1, emphasis added)

sec.p: Various terms have been used to describe what such leadership might entail; leadership descriptors remain more numerous than evidence to confirm direct benefits for children and young people. Few approaches are given more attention than the importance of working in teams. Such an emphasis, however, is neither understood nor applied uniformly. What is described as team-working can be of large corporate dimensions (West, 2004), be made up of many tiny interactions, even on a daily basis (Rihani and Geyer, 2001), and/or comprise team formations of limited tenure, or what Hammick et al. (2009: 54) describe as ‘teams of the moment’. Many services purporting to serve children’s needs contain elements of all these. A variant of distributed leadership, called team leadership, describes the trend, often in the absence of common understandings about purposes and scale. More recently, in an evaluation of a multi-professional development programme organized by the National College, Simkins and Garrick (2010), for example, note how few ‘team’ members actually saw themselves working in teams, often preferring the terms networks and/or communities of practice. Provocatively, Huxham and Vangen (2005) have referred to the phenomenon in terms of ‘leaderless leadership’.

Still more adjectives have been applied to leadership considered appropriate for multi-agency/inter-professional working. Whittington (2003) refers to ‘elective’ leadership in terms not dissimilar to Kirwan et al’s. (2008) use of ‘contributive’. Elective leadership is also a ‘style’ described by Miller et al. (2001), based on six case studies of multi-professional work in Health and Social Care. From such a perspective, elective leadership occurs, it is asserted, when responsibility for leadership is assigned to all those in multi-professional teams. Members continue to work autonomously, maintaining separate roles, but express a value in learning from others in the partnership. Here, we note a move from ‘leaderless’ leadership (Huxham and Vangen, 2005), through team leadership, towards a perspective of ‘everyone being a leader’ in multi-agency teams.

Or, inter-professional advocates have assumed that with goodwill, the best of attention to team work, and an intensification of inter-professional capacity building, models of ‘servant leadership’ (Neill et al., 2007; Spears and Lawrence, 2002) are equally or simultaneously appropriate. Hammick et al. (2009: 55) consider the fit between ‘servant leadership’ and new demands to be inter-professional:

disp-quote.p: The integration of servant leadership principles in practice has less to do with directing other people and more to do with serving their needs and in fostering the use of shared power in an effort to enhance effectiveness in the professional role.

sec.p: The extent to which shared power is a feature of systemic development is considered next.

sec.title: ‘Schoolification’ and System Leadership
sec.p: The concept of system leadership is one which has been ‘grabbed’ enthusiastically as an approach which appears to overcome previous shortcomings in defining or applying collaborative practices in the best interests of children and young people (Higham et al., 2009; Hopkins and Higham, 2007) notably in relation to both children’s learning and schools. Notwithstanding its purported commitment to the systemic development of communities containing multiple agencies, the approach is largely school-centric, with headteachers/principals viewed as having key roles in the ‘systemic development of communities containing students other than their own’ (Hopkins and Higham, 2007: 148) Advocated as part of a ‘new professional movement’ in the development of school staff and principals, even the most enthusiastic recognize tensions in the advocacy of system leadership as ‘national policy’ or as ‘a professional movement’ (Hopkins and Higham, 2007: 147). So, while there seems to be an emerging view of leadership as one which might be collective, ‘stretched’ across multiple services, alliances, and authorities, and which seeks to bring about inter-service collaboration, the system approach seems firmly anchored, at least in the ELM literature, as central to school leadership capacity building. ‘System leadership’ also tends to accept rather than seriously challenge the tensions between leadership of inter-/multi-agency activities and current forms of institutional self-interest and accountability. Following Hartley (2010a: 360) (albeit in relation to distributed leadership), ‘its coming to the fore seems to have been pragmatic … rather than a response to deep structural changes in the economic and social orders’.

As in mainstream education policy (DFES, 2005c), headteachers are increasingly identified in the inter-service literature as visionaries and drivers, who are successful in engaging others in both multi- and inter-agency initiatives; Coleman (2006: 35) for example, refers to them taking a ‘strong strategic and symbolic lead’. Several writers consider school leaders, in particular, to be especially important in the early stages of potential collaboration between agencies (Coleman, 2006; Cummings, 2008; Kirwan et al., 2008; Siraj Blatchford et al., 2007) and with key emphases upon headteachers. Kirwan et al. (2008) go further to suggest that headteachers ought to encourage external agencies to engage with the vision of the school, an approach described by Cohen et al. (2004: 6) as ‘schoolification’, when schools develop increased power over the lives of children, and dominate professionals from other agencies. This raises issues about the complementarity, sometimes assumed, between ‘the vision of the school’, the multiple purposes and objectives of inter-agency collaboration, and the needs of children and young people. (The earlier reference to Mordaunt (1999) and ‘predatory partnerships’ might seem apposite here.) Meanwhile, research evidence from Huxham and Vangen (2005) indicates the degree of challenge in agreeing clear visions and purposes for collaborative partnerships. Others refer to the need for clarity of purpose, aims and responsibilities rather than vision (Atkinson et al., 2001; Hardy, 1999; Sloper, 2004), and for purposive strategic leadership of multi-agency cooperation whether by steering groups (Sloper, 2004) or strategic planning fora (Yerbury, 1997).

sec.title: Preparing Collaborative Leaders
sec.p: Notwithstanding a vacuum in theoretical development, there are ongoing programmes to train many key staff involved in recent forms of inter-agency work. This follows belated recognition that inter-agency work also required considerations of inter-agency leadership (Close, 2011), and includes ‘official’ recognition of the problems of multi-agency work, ‘the difficulty of managing … complexity in an evolving policy context’ (DFES, 2006a: 2, 7), and in ‘an environment where professionals may be working to conflicting agendas’. Government responses have been predictable: a framework for professional development and the emergence of national standards in terms of the skills, knowledge and behaviours needed for those working across services. Such developments reveal rational responses to managing inter-service work by evoking clearer structures and systems of performance management, standards indicators, and measurable outcomes, despite the acknowledgement of complexity and conflict noted above.

When the ECM agenda was introduced, there were few professional development opportunities appropriate for those leading new multi-professional teams. Several research and evaluation reports noted paucity in training opportunities for those facilitating work across agencies (Anning et al., 2006; DFES, 2006a, 2006b; Edwards et al., 2010; Hartle et al., 2008). Yet, when the Hartle et al. (2008) undertook research into the role and development needs of middle managers in multi-agency settings for the Hay Group, they found that even in post-training contexts, there was a lack of clarity among participants about what constituted effective inter- or multi-agency work. Subsequently, training programmes for middle managers were developed, led by the Children’s Workforce Development Council (CWDC), along with a National Qualification for Integrated Centre Leadership (NQICL), led by the National College. Its focus has been on developing ‘internal integration’ between personal and professional values and behaviours in order to help leaders in Children’s Centres to address the ‘complex management of conflicting roles and responsibilities’ (NPQICL, 2010). In setting out the benefits of this qualification, the programme emphasizes:

list-item.p: opportunities to reflect in-depth on your leadership;
access to a mentor to support, guide and challenge you;
a leadership learning journal to record thoughts and reflections about key incidents which provides a focus for mentoring sessions;
a centre based assessment visit towards the end of the programme. (NPQICL, 2010)

sec.p: The programme takes an experiential approach to learning, enabling participants to contribute to its design, and to develop ‘learning communities’ that draw on participants’ professional experience and knowledge. What appears to be lacking, however, is any clear indication of deep theoretical and critical analysis. Rather, the model of leadership preparation is to enable participants (following NCSL, 2008: 10) to ask: ‘what is it like being a leader in an integrated Children’s Centre and how can I best respond to its challenges?’ While there is clear value in creating a course which encourages the participation of leaders from a wide variety of backgrounds, little attention appears to have been given to the theory-practice nexus. On the contrary, fears were that ‘the assignments might become too academically orientated – at the expense of the professional-practitioner focus’ (NCSL, 2008: 9).

sec.title: Taking Stock and Moving Forward
sec.p: This article has sought to shed light on the extent to which recent trends towards collaborative inter-service provision are matched by the development of appropriate leadership theories and/or practices. Published evidence suggests that the term ‘collaborative leadership’ is open to almost any kind of definition that counters a strictly autocratic position, and that even the latter has the capacity to be absorbed into so-called collaborative models/systems.

In part, this is because terms like collaboration, cooperation, coordination, federation and networking are used inter-changeably with multi-, inter-service, and systems provision, and at a variety of levels, with little recourse to ‘new’ theory other than in terms of relatively minor adjustments to those which have dominated uni-service provision, frequently evident in the schools literature. In the ELM field, the interrogative lens, with some exceptions noted earlier, rarely focuses on leadership that moves beyond the internal organization of schooling. This suggests that the time is ripe for a new locus of attention that extends beyond the last generation’s focus upon schools as single sites for school improvement and effectiveness towards theoretical and research engagement with interventions that move beyond the school, and demand engagement with more than school-based professionals and services.

This suggests at least four focal points of interest for the education leadership field: the first would centre upon new understandings about what being an inter-agency leader actually means in practice, not least in contexts where leadership influence has, to date, relied more on orchestration tactics than positional power. The second might focus on ‘inter-professionality’ as a ‘new’ (and contestable) form of professionalism, and consider its implications for the cultural transformation of work-based practices. Indeed, new approaches to what actually constitute the bases and boundaries of education work and leadership may be overdue, requiring research activity across a range of knowledge disciplines and professional boundaries. Third, it follows that leadership development opportunities ought to incorporate deeper, more intellectually supported approaches, which are both people and organization minded. Finally, investigations about the contribution of each of the above in meeting the diverse educational and social needs of children and young people would seem essential.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Our desk research suggests that a meeting of minds in terms of the literatures that span Education, Health, Social Work and Social Care is, as yet, only barely discernible, and involves diverse interpretations about how collaboration is being translated into practice. Moreover, theoretical stagnation persists in part because policy tends to be ‘taken’ rather than scrutinized. Notions of boundary-breaking leadership that also run counter to organizational or professional self-interest and accountability remain largely unchallenged other than in terms of developing leaders who have the resilience to cope with contradiction.

While hierarchy and the market are likely to accelerate as key organizing principles within and beyond schools, hospitals, and care organizations, momentous changes are occurring in terms of the breaking down of long-standing alliances among schools, between schools and local authorities, schools and universities, public and private services, and between service users and an increasingly diverse range of providers. Not only is there uncertainty about what collaboration is but also about with whom leaders ought to collaborate. This suggests that even the relatively novel aspects of inter-service leadership implicated in recent TAC models face imminent modification, even disintegration, since many of the models evoked by terms like federation, networking, partnership, collaboration, and alliance making, are, as we write, being remoulded or dismantled. To use a dance analogy, as the ‘music stops’, organizations may need ‘to change partners’ (again).

A less pessimistic orientation might be to argue, following Gronn (2010), that the leadership models which recent generations of leaders have been required to ‘buy into’ have never, in reality, existed, other than in idealized forms. This presents opportunities. Applying the term leadership as a set of changing ‘configurations’ (Gronn, 2010: 422), in which individual leadership co-exists with various forms of group-based or project-orientated leadership formations within and across organizations, makes it possible for futures-orientated theorists to work with professionals to define the kinds of ‘capabilities’ and professional and work-based cultures needed to lead learning ethically in multi-faceted, inter-professional and inter-agency environments. Perhaps more than ever we need to investigate interventions most likely to succeed in maximizing opportunities for children and young people whose needs the leadership field purports to serve.
